sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: KVP is a government-backed savings certificate scheme launched in 1988, aimed initially at farmers but now open to all Indian residents. It offers secure, fixed returns by doubling the investment over a pre-set tenure.[^1][^2][^3]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Investors buy certificates from post offices/banks.
- At a current interest rate of **7.5% per annum**, the investment doubles in **115 months** (9 years, 7 months).
- Compounded annually, interest is paid only at maturity; premature encashment possible after 2.5 years.[^2][^3]
- Minimum investment is ₹1,000; no maximum limit.
- Nomination and certificate transfer features available.[^3][^4][^2]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- All resident Indians (adults, minors via guardian) can invest; NRIs and HUFs cannot.[^5][^6]
- Joint holding permitted, as well as purchase on behalf of a minor.[^3]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Collect and fill KVP Form-A at any India Post branch or select banks; submit KYC documents.
- Certificates are issued physically or via e-mode; online registration available through internet banking for some.[^7]
- Nomination facility is available.[^2][^3]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- No tax deduction on principal/interest; interest is taxable.
- Premature withdrawal only after 2.5 years, with lower returns.
- Transferable between people (once) and post offices.[^8][^3]
- Widely accessible across India.[^3]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: The POTD is a fixed deposit scheme offered via India Post, providing guaranteed returns over tenures of 1, 2, 3, or 5 years. It closely resembles a bank FD but with government backing.[^12][^13][^14][^15]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Lump sum invested for a selected term.
- Current interest rates (as of Sept. 2025): 1yr—6.9%, 2yr—7.0%, 3yr—7.1%, 5yr—7.5% (compounded quarterly, paid annually).
- Minimum investment: ₹1,000 (multiples of ₹100); no upper limit.
- 5-year deposit eligible for Section 80C tax deduction; interest is fully taxable.[^13][^14][^16]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- All resident individuals (adults, joint holders up to 3, minors via guardian).
- Not open to NRIs, HUFs, trusts, or organizations.[^14][^17][^13]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Available at any India Post branch; some authorized banks may offer POTD.
- Provide application form, KYC (PAN, Aadhaar, address proof), and deposit.
- Account can be transferred between post offices.[^16][^13][^14]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Multiple accounts allowed.
- Premature withdrawals allowed after 6 months, with interest penalty.
- Nomination facility available.
- 5-year TD qualifies for tax benefits; TDS applicable above limit.[^13][^14][^16]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: PMVVY is a government-subsidized pension scheme for Indian senior citizens (60+), launched in 2017 and managed by LIC. The plan guarantees steady pension income irrespective of market volatility.[^19][^20][^21][^22]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Invest a one-time purchase price (₹1.5 lakh to ₹15 lakh) with a fixed policy term of 10 years.
- Choose pension payouts: monthly/quarterly/half-yearly/yearly.
- Guarantees ~7.4% to 8% annual returns (reset periodically).[^23][^24][^22]
- On maturity (10 years), initial investment is refunded, or in case of death, paid to the nominee.[^22][^25]
- Loan (after 3 years) and premature exit (for critical illness) allowed.[^25][^22]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Indian resident, 60 years and above; no maximum entry age.[^24][^22][^25]
- Not available to NRIs or HUFs.[^24][^22]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Purchase through LIC offices/agents or directly online at licindia.in.[^24]
- Submit PMVVY application, KYC (age proof, address, PAN), photographs, and bank details.[^22][^24]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Maximum investment: ₹15 lakh per senior citizen.
- Minimum pension: ₹1,000/month; Maximum: ₹9,250/month.
- No tax deduction under Sec 80C; pension income is taxable.
- Safe, sovereign-backed, option for retirees seeking regular payout and capital protection.[^25][^22][^24]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: MSSC is a government-backed small savings scheme, launched in April 2023 for women and girls. Available till March 31, 2025, MSSC promotes financial independence and savings for women by offering secure, attractive returns for a short tenure.[^1][^2][^3]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Single-holder deposit (minimum ₹1,000, maximum ₹2 lakh per woman/girl; multiples of ₹100).
- Tenure: 2 years; interest rate **7.5% per annum**, compounded quarterly and paid on maturity.
- Partial withdrawal up to 40% allowed after 1 year; premature closure under specific conditions (death/critical illness).[^4][^5][^6]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- All resident Indian women and girl children.
- Guardians can open accounts for minor girls.
- No upper age limit; only single-holder accounts permitted.[^6][^7][^8]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Open at post offices or authorized banks by submitting MSSC application, Aadhaar, PAN, address proof, and photo.
- Payment by cash or cheque.
- Certificate issued after verification; nomination facility available.[^5][^4]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Interest income is taxable.
- Multiple accounts possible with minimum 3-month gap, total deposit capped at ₹2 lakh.
- Safe, government-backed, short-term savings option with higher return than most FDs.[^2][^5]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: The RBI FRB is a market-linked, government-backed bond for Indian residents and HUFs, introduced in July 2020. Its interest rate "floats"—resets every six months based on NSC rates, providing inflation protection and regular payouts.[^9][^10][^11][^12]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Invest minimum ₹1,000 (no maximum limit) for 7-year tenure.
- **Interest rate: NSC rate + 0.35%; currently 8.05% (July–Dec 2025)**, paid semi-annually (Jan/Jul).
- Not tradable, not transferable except to nominee/legal heir.
- Premature withdrawal only for senior citizens: possible after 4–6 years depending on age (penalty applies).[^13][^14][^15]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Indian residents (individuals) and Hindu Undivided Families (HUFs).
- Joint holding, minors via guardian allowed.
- NRIs not eligible.[^10][^14][^16][^13]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Apply at banks authorized to sell RBI bonds (e.g., SBI, HDFC, Axis).
- Provide filled application, KYC (PAN, Aadhaar, address proof), cancelled cheque.
- Payment by cheque/online; Bond Ledger Account issued.[^17][^10]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Interest fully taxable; TDS applies if annual interest > ₹10,000.
- No loan/collateral, not tradable on any exchange.
- Safe, sovereign guarantee; ideal for conservative investors and retirees.[^11][^9]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: PMJDY is the central financial inclusion initiative, launched in August 2014, providing universal access to basic banking services for all Indian citizens, especially targeting the unbanked and underserved.[^19][^20][^21][^22]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Open zero-balance savings account at any bank/post office (minors >10 via guardian).
- RuPay debit card issued; beneficiaries gain direct subsidy/DBT access.
- **Accident insurance cover ₹2 lakh; ₹30,000 life cover for early adopters.** OD facility for Aadhar-linked accounts, up to ₹10,000; interest earned on deposits.[^20][^23][^21]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Any Indian citizen (including minors via guardian).
- No age, income, employment restriction; ideal for unbanked, rural and urban poor.[^24][^25][^26]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Open at any bank branch or Business Correspondent (Bank Mitra) outlet.
- Aadhar preferred; other government ID accepted. Biometric KYC for low-risk cases.
- Immediate account opening possible; options for digital onboarding.[^23][^22]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- No minimum balance; overdraft benefit available after 6 months of satisfactory operation.
- PMJDY accounts eligible for all central welfare DBT.
- Scheme supports financial literacy, micro-insurance, and pension for exclusion-prone families.[^27][^28][^20]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: NSAP is a centrally sponsored welfare program by the Government of India launched on 15th August 1995 to provide financial assistance to poor households in case of old age, death of the breadwinner, and maternity. It aims to ensure minimum national standards of social assistance in addition to state schemes.[^1][^2][^3]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Provides social pensions to elderly above 60, widows, and persons with disabilities below poverty line.
- National Family Benefit Scheme offers one-time financial assistance to bereaved families of breadwinners.
- Annapurna scheme provides food grains to senior citizens covered by NOAPS but not receiving pension.
- Implementation through state rural development departments; pensions disbursed monthly.[^4][^5]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Must belong to Below Poverty Line (BPL) families.
- Age criteria:
    - Old Age Pension: 60 years and above.
    - Widow Pension: 40–79 years.
    - Disability Pension: 18–79 years with disability ≥ 80%.
- Death of breadwinner covers 18–64 years.[^6][^7]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Application through state governments via designated rural development offices.
- Required documents include identification, income proof/BPL status, age proof.
- Pension amount and beneficiary data updated through NSAP portal.[^8][^9]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Fully funded by Government of India.
- Covers both rural and urban poor.
- Promotes social equity by ensuring minimum support.[^2][^7]

meta.scheme: National Social Security Fund (NSSF) [Indian Context: National Small Savings Fund]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: In India, NSSF refers to the National Small Savings Fund, created by pooling money from small savings schemes like PPF, NSC, and others. It is used as a government fund for financing fiscal deficits and lending to states under certain terms.[^10][^11]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Collections from various small saving schemes credited to NSSF.
- Funds utilized by central/state governments for fiscal deficit financing.
- Managed under the Ministry of Finance with investment policies adhering to government guidelines.
- Supports government borrowing and provides liquidity to small saving schemes.[^11][^10]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Not a direct beneficiary scheme; applicable to holders of various small saving instruments.
- Schemes contributing to NSSF have their individual eligibility (e.g., NSC, PPF, SCSS).
- The fund acts as a backend resource for the government and public financial institutions.[^10]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- No direct application; access through investing in small saving schemes accredited to NSSF.
- Invest in schemes such as NSC, PPF, SCSS at authorized banks/post offices.[^10]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Supports government’s borrowing and expenditure plans.
- Interest rates on small savings are rationalized with budget considerations.
- Crucial for fiscal planning and economic management.[^11]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: NEMMP, launched in 2013 by the Government of India, is a comprehensive plan to promote hybrid and electric vehicles (xEVs) in India, aimed at national fuel security, pollution reduction, and development of domestic automotive manufacturing.[^12][^13]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Provides subsidies for electric vehicle purchases, especially under the FAME (Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Hybrid \& Electric Vehicles) scheme.
- Supports development of EV infrastructure like charging stations.
- Encourages R\&D, manufacturing capabilities, and consumer awareness for EV adoption.
- Targets deployment of 6-7 million electric/hybrid vehicles by 2020 (targets updated for 2025).[^13][^14][^15]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Manufacturers and buyers of electric and hybrid vehicles.
- Fleet owners, individual consumers, startups in EV ecosystem.
- Beneficiary details vary per sub-scheme under NEMMP and FAME guidelines.[^16][^14]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- EV buyers apply for subsidies through authorized vehicle dealerships.
- Manufacturers apply for production incentives via Department of Heavy Industry portals.
- Charging infrastructure projects approved under ministry frameworks.[^16]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- NEMMP focuses on sustainability and energy security.
- Encourages electric two-wheelers, three-wheelers, passenger cars, and buses.
- Subsidy rationalization and market development ongoing to boost EV penetration.[^17][^18]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: PM-KISAN is a Central Sector scheme launched in December 2018 by the Government of India to provide income support to all small and marginal landholding farmer families across India.[^1][^2]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Provides eligible farmers ₹6,000 per year in three equal installments of ₹2,000 transferred directly to their Aadhaar-linked bank accounts.
- Funds are meant to supplement the financial needs of farmers for agricultural inputs and domestic requirements.
- Uses Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) to ensure timely and transparent payments.[^3][^4]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Landholding farmers with cultivable land in their names.
- Household defined as husband, wife, and minor children.
- Excludes institutional landholders, government employees with pensions above ₹10,000, professionals like doctors, lawyers, income tax payers, and certain other categories.
- Verification through mandatory e-KYC.[^5][^6]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Farmers can register online at the official PM-KISAN portal or through state agriculture departments.
- Required documents: Aadhaar, bank details, landholding proof.
- Application status and installment details available online.[^7][^8]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Fully funded by the central government.
- Aims to ease liquidity constraints and reduce dependence on moneylenders.
- Covers approximately all cultivable landholding families subject to exclusions.[^9][^10]

meta.scheme: National Scheme of Welfare of Fishermen

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: A centrally sponsored scheme introduced in 1992 to provide financial assistance and support to small-scale fishermen for improving their livelihoods and well-being.[^11][^12]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Provides aid for construction of houses, community halls (for recreation and work), and installation of tube wells for drinking water.
- Includes group accident insurance covering death, total permanent disability, and partial permanent disability.
- Implements a savings-cum-relief scheme offering financial support during lean fishing seasons.
- Funds are matched by Central and State Governments.[^13][^12][^14]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Full-time fishermen licensed or identified by their respective State/UT Governments, including marine and inland fishermen.
- Priority given to those below poverty line (BPL).
- Members of fishermen cooperatives or welfare societies.[^15][^16]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Apply at the nearest FISHCOPFED office or state fisheries department.
- Contributions collected and forwarded by cooperative societies.
- Required documents: Aadhaar, Voter ID, income certificate, fisherman registration.
- States implement the scheme and ensure fund allocation and oversight.[^12][^14]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Insurance premium partly subsidized by Central and State Governments.
- Aims to develop sustainable fishermen villages and improve welfare.
- Provides social security and financial stability to fishing communities.[^17][^18]

sections.title: Useful Links
sections.body:

- Fisheries department resources \& cooperative societies.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: Launched on May 1, 2016, by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, PMUY aims to provide clean cooking fuel (LPG connections) to women from Below Poverty Line (BPL) households, improving health outcomes and empowering women.[^19][^20][^21]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Provides free LPG connection with deposit-free cylinder.
- Initial free stove and first refill provided under the scheme.
- Subsidized LPG cylinders available for connected households.
- Uses SECC-2011 data and BPL lists to identify beneficiaries.[^22][^23]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Women aged 18 years or above from BPL families with no existing LPG connection.
- Priority to SC/ST, OBC, Antyodaya beneficiaries, and other vulnerable groups.
- Household income limits defined by State/UTs for eligibility.[^24][^25]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Online application via official PMUY website or through LPG distributors (IOC, BPCL, HPCL).
- Offline application at nearest LPG distributor offices.
- Required documents include Aadhaar, BPL ration card, address proof, and photographs.[^26][^27]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Scheme has distributed over 10 crore LPG connections.
- Reduces indoor air pollution, improves health of women and children.
- Supports environmental sustainability by reducing reliance on firewood and fossil fuels.[^28][^23]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: Launched in 2003 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, PMSSY aims to correct regional imbalances in the availability of affordable and reliable tertiary healthcare across India. It focuses on establishing new AIIMS-like institutes and upgrading existing government medical colleges to enhance healthcare delivery and medical education in underserved regions.[^1][^2][^3]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Two components: (1) Establishment of new AIIMS institutions equipped with advanced medical facilities and teaching capabilities, (2) Upgradation of selected existing government medical colleges with super-specialty blocks and trauma centers.
- The Government funds 100% of new AIIMS and shares cost of upgrades with states for GMCs.
- The scheme enhances healthcare infrastructure, specialist medical services, and medical education opportunities.[^2][^4][^1]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- No direct beneficiary eligibility since it is an infrastructure scheme benefiting all citizens by improving tertiary healthcare access.
- Benefit primarily for patients needing advanced medical services and students seeking medical education in upgraded institutions.[^1][^2]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Not applicable; healthcare services available to all at the AIIMS and upgraded government medical colleges countrywide.
- Patients can access services by visiting these government hospitals as per standard admission and treatment protocols.[^2]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- The AIIMS institutions are autonomous bodies governed under the AIIMS Act.
- PMSSY is being implemented in phases with multiple new AIIMS operational and several GMCs upgraded.
- It helps reduce healthcare disparities across states by providing quality tertiary care.[^5][^1]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: PMJJBY is a government-supported life insurance scheme launched in 2015, offering affordable term life insurance to individuals aged 18-50 years with a bank account. It provides financial security with a coverage amount in case of the insured's death due to any reason.[^8][^9][^10]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- One-year renewable term insurance policy with coverage of ₹2 lakh.
- Annual premium is ₹436, auto-debited from the insured’s bank or post office account.
- Insurance coverage starts from June 1 or date of enrollment.
- No medical examination needed; coverage includes death from any cause after a 30-day waiting period.[^11][^12][^13]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Indian citizens aged 18-50 years with a savings bank/post office account.
- Joint account holders can individually enroll.
- Coverage continues till age 55 after enrollment.[^14][^15]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Enroll via bank branches, post offices, or online portals.
- Provide consent for auto-debit of premium and basic KYC documents (Aadhaar, bank account details).
- Can be renewed annually with simple process.[^9][^16]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Provides ₹2 lakh coverage on death due to any cause.
- Premium is extremely affordable.
- Tax benefits under Section 80C apply.
- Over 23 crore enrollments till 2025; large claim disbursal record for poor and rural sections.[^10][^13]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: PMSBY is a government-backed personal accident insurance scheme launched in May 2015, offering affordable risk coverage against accidental death and disability to individuals aged 18-70 years with bank accounts at a nominal annual premium.[^18][^19]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Annual renewable insurance policy with premium ₹20 per year (₹1.67/month).
- Coverage includes ₹2 lakh for accidental death and total permanent disability, ₹1 lakh for partial permanent disability.
- Policy runs from June 1 to May 31 every year, premiums auto-debited from savings bank/post office accounts.[^20][^21]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Individuals aged 18-70 years with a savings bank/post office account.
- One membership per individual, even if multiple accounts.
- Aadhaar linkage mandatory for KYC and enrollment.[^22][^20]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Enrollment through banks/post offices or online portals.
- Required documents include Aadhaar, bank account details, signed consent for auto-debit.
- Easy renewal or discontinuation yearly.[^23][^24]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Low-cost coverage with significant financial protection for accidental death/disability.
- To claim, beneficiaries provide death/disability certificates to respective bank.
- Over 51 crore enrollments reported with substantial claims disbursed.[^25][^26]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: POMIS is a government-backed savings scheme offered by India Post, designed to provide a fixed monthly income through interest payouts on a one-time deposit. It is best suited for conservative investors seeking regular, risk-free income.[^1][^2][^3]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- A lump sum amount is deposited for a tenure of 5 years.
- The scheme pays interest (currently **7.4% per annum** as of Q3 2025) monthly, credited to the investor’s post office savings account.
- On maturity, the principal is returned and may be reinvested.[^4][^5][^2][^6]
- Minimum deposit: ₹1,000; Maximum: ₹9 lakh (individual) / ₹15 lakh (joint).
- Premature closure after 1 year is allowed with penalties (2% deduction if closed between 1-3 years, 1% if between 3-5 years).[^5][^6]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Any **resident individual** (including minors above 10 years through a guardian).
- Joint accounts (up to 3 adults) permitted.
- NRIs and entities (HUFs, trusts, etc.) not eligible.[^7][^8][^9]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Visit any post office branch and fill out the POMIS application form.
- Submit KYC documents (age, ID, address, PAN, photographs).
- Make the deposit via cash/cheque.
- Nomination facility is available.
- In-person application is required; online application is not available.[^10][^11][^3]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- No tax benefit on principal or interest, and interest is taxable as per income slab.
- No TDS on interest payments.
- Multiple accounts possible, but investment limit applies across all combined accounts.
- Post-maturity, unclaimed funds continue to earn interest at post office savings account rates for up to 2 years.[^6][^3][^5]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: NSC is a popular government-saving bond for individuals, promoting small and mid-level savings with assured returns and tax benefits under Section 80C. It is issued by India Post and is especially favored by conservative investors for fixed, guaranteed growth.[^12][^13][^14][^15]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Investor purchases NSC certificates (now in e-mode) for a lock-in of 5 years.
- The interest is compounded annually (currently **7.7% p.a.** for 2025) and paid out only at maturity.
- Minimum deposit: ₹1,000; no maximum investment limit.
- Investment amount and accrued interest are paid in a lump sum at maturity.
- Interest for the first 4 years is eligible for tax rebate as it is considered reinvested.[^15][^16][^17]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Any **resident individual** can invest.
- NRIs, HUFs, and trusts not permitted (exception: Karta in personal capacity).
- Accounts may be held individually (including minors via guardian) or jointly (up to 3 adults).[^16][^17][^18][^15]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Visit any India Post branch.
- Fill out the NSC application form and submit KYC proofs (Aadhaar, PAN, address).
- Pay the investment amount via cash, cheque, or e-transfer.
- Nomination facility available.
- E-certificates are now standard (physical certificates discontinued since 2016).[^13][^19][^14]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Tax benefit under Section 80C up to ₹1.5 lakh invested per year.
- Interest is taxable but eligible for deduction for the first four years.
- Certificates can be pledged as loan collateral.
- No premature withdrawal, except in specific cases (death of holder, court order).
- Transferable between post offices and persons (once during tenure).[^14][^20][^15]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: The Post Office Recurring Deposit (PORD) is a government-backed savings scheme allowing regular monthly deposits for a fixed term, offering secure, steady growth for individuals prioritizing disciplined savings.[^1][^2][^3]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Deposit a fixed amount monthly (minimum ₹100, no maximum, in multiples of ₹10) for 5 years (60 installments).
- **Interest Rate (Q3 2025): 6.7% p.a.** (compounded quarterly).
- On maturity, receive principal plus accrued interest.
- Allows rebate on advance payment of 6+ installments; allows default with penalty.
- Loan available after 1 year (12 installments) up to 50% of balance; premature closure after 3 years.[^2][^3][^4]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Open to all resident individuals (adults, minors above 10 years, guardians for minors/persons of unsound mind).
- Joint accounts (up to 3 adults) permitted.[^5]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Visit any post office with the filled RD application, KYC documents (ID/address proof, PAN/Aadhaar), and photographs.
- Provide deposit via cash/cheque.
- Nomination available; account transferable between post offices.[^6][^7]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- No TDS on interest; interest is fully taxable.
- Multiple RDs can be held.
- Loan facility, account conversion (single/joint or minor/major), default fee for missed payments.
- Account can be extended for further 5 years after maturity.[^7][^2][^6]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: Launched in May 2015, APY is a central government pension scheme targeting workers in the unorganized sector, guaranteeing monthly pension after age 60.[^10][^11][^12][^13]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Subscribers (age 18–40) make monthly/quarterly/half-yearly contributions until age 60, auto-debited from bank account.
- Offers fixed pension: ₹1,000, ₹2,000, ₹3,000, ₹4,000, or ₹5,000/month based on contribution.[^11][^13]
- Pension is guaranteed by the central government; spouse eligible for pension on death of subscriber. On both deaths, nominee gets corpus.[^14][^15]
- Subscribers can change contribution amount annually.[^11]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Open to all Indian citizens aged 18 to 40 years (cannot be an income tax-payer, as per latest norms).
- Must have a savings/post office account.
- Not covered under any statutory social security scheme.[^13][^16][^17]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Apply via bank or post office holding the savings account.
- Submit APY registration form, along with Aadhaar, mobile number, KYC.
- Contribution auto-debited.
- Nomination available.[^16][^17]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Minimum period of contribution: 20 years.
- Co-contribution by government for eligible non-taxpayers who joined scheme between specific early periods.
- Tax benefits under Section 80CCD.
- Withdrawals allowed before 60 only in death/terminal illness cases.[^18][^17]

sections.body: PM-SYM is a voluntary, contributory pension scheme for old age protection of unorganized sector workers, assuring social security with a lifetime minimum monthly pension.[^19][^20][^21]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Workers (entry age 18–40 years) contribute monthly till age 60; government matches contribution.
- **Minimum assured pension: ₹3,000/month** paid after age 60.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: The **Senior Citizens Savings Scheme (SCSS)** is a government-backed savings scheme tailor-made for senior citizens in India, offering safe and regular income with attractive interest rates and tax benefits.[^1][^2][^3]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: SCSS was introduced in 2004 by the Indian government to provide financial security for individuals aged 60 years and above after retirement. This scheme offers steady quarterly interest payouts, government-assured safety, and tax-saving benefits under Section 80C.[^4][^2][^3][^1]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- Eligible individuals deposit a lump sum (minimum ₹1,000; maximum ₹30 lakh) in the scheme via a post office or authorized bank.
- The prevailing interest rate (currently 8.2% per annum for Q2 FY 2025-26) is paid out quarterly and remains fixed for the deposit tenure.
- The scheme has a tenure of 5 years, extendable once by 3 years after maturity.
- Premature withdrawals are allowed with penalties.
- Interest is taxable, though deductible up to ₹1.5 lakh under Section 80C of the Income Tax Act (old regime).[^5][^6][^3][^7]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- Any Indian resident aged 60 years or above.
- Individuals aged 55-60 years who have retired under superannuation/VRS can invest within a month of receiving retirement benefits.
- NRIs, PIOs, and Hindu Undivided Families (HUFs) are not eligible.
- Joint accounts possible only with the spouse.[^8][^9][^10][^11]

sections.title: How to Apply
sections.body:
- Visit a post office or an authorized public/private bank branch.
- Fill out and submit Form A (application form) along with required documents (age proof, identity proof, address proof, PAN, Aadhaar, photographs).
- Deposit the investment amount (in multiples of ₹1,000, cash allowed up to ₹1 lakh; above ₹1 lakh via cheque).
- Nominate a beneficiary if desired.[^12][^13][^14]
- Online application facility is not available; in-person branch visit is required.[^13]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Quarterly interest credited to the linked bank account.
- Maximum investment limit is ₹30 lakh (combined across all SCSS accounts).
- Investment can be extended for 3 years post initial 5-year term.
- Premature withdrawal possible with penalties (no interest if closed before 1 year; 1.5% penalty after 1 year but before 2 years; 1% penalty after 2 years but before 5 years).
- TDS is applicable if annual interest exceeds ₹50,000, but Form 15H can be filed to seek exemption if total income is below taxable limit.
- Account can be transferred between banks and post offices in India.[^6][^3][^7][^8]

sections.title: Introduction
sections.body: Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana (SSY) is a Government of India small savings scheme designed for the girl child. It offers long-term, govt-backed growth with tax benefits (EEE in most cases) and is commonly opened via India Post or authorized banks.[^1][^2]

sections.title: How the Scheme Works
sections.body:
- You open an SSY account for a girl child and deposit money during the **contribution period** (commonly up to 15 years from account opening).
- Interest is notified by the government (quarterly), and interest is credited as per SSY rules.
- The account typically matures at **21 years** from account opening (subject to scheme rules).
- Deposits can be made as per scheme rules (often flexible during the year; many people treat it as monthly for convenience).[^1][^3]

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.body:
- For a **girl child** (as per SSY rules).
- Account is opened by parent/guardian.
- Limits on number of accounts per family may apply (as per the latest rules).[^1][^2]

sections.title: Deposits, Tenure & Maturity
sections.body:
- **Deposit period:** usually up to **15 years** from account opening.
- **Maturity:** usually **21 years** from account opening.
- Minimum/maximum annual contribution limits apply as per notified SSY rules (varies by period; check the latest notification).[^1][^3][^4]

sections.title: Withdrawals & Closure
sections.body:
- Partial withdrawal is typically allowed after the child attains a specified age (commonly 18) for education-related needs, as per rules.
- Premature closure rules may apply for specific circumstances.
- Marriage-related closure rules may apply as per latest guidelines.[^1][^3]

sections.title: Taxation (Indicative)
sections.body:
- Contributions are often eligible under **Section 80C** (subject to the overall 80C cap).
- Interest and maturity are commonly treated as **EEE** (subject to prevailing tax rules).
- Always verify with latest income-tax guidance for your situation.[^5][^6]

sections.title: How to Open
sections.body:
- Open at an India Post branch or at authorized banks.
- KYC documents of guardian and proof of child (as per bank/post office requirements) are required.
- Nomination/guardian details are captured during account opening.[^1][^2]

sections.title: Important Points to Note
sections.body:
- Interest rates change over time (not fixed forever). Keep an eye on quarterly small-savings rate notifications.
- SSY is long-term and goal-based; plan liquidity separately.
- Rules can change; rely on official sources for latest limits and operational details.[^4][^1]
